df-proset
blocks.content: Define the class of preordered sets, or prosets. A proset is a set equipped with a preorder, that is, a transitive and reflexive relation. Preorders are a natural generalization of partial orders which need not be antisymmetric: there may be pairs of elements such that each is "less than or equal to" the other, so that both elements have the same order-theoretic properties (in some sense, there is a "tie" among them). If a preorder is required to be antisymmetric, that is, there is no such "tie", then one obtains a partial order. If a preorder is required to be symmetric, that is, all comparable elements are tied, then one obtains an equivalence relation. Every preorder naturally factors into these two notions: the "tie" relation on a proset is an equivalence relation, and the quotient under that equivalence relation is a partial order. (Contributed by FL, 17-Nov-2014.) (Revised by Stefan O'Rear, 31-Jan-2015.)

axiom df-proset(setvar s0, setvar s1, setvar s2, setvar s3, setvar s4, setvar s5) {
  ⊢ Proset = { s0 |[(Base ` s0)/ s1][(le ` s0)/ s2]∀(s3 ∈ s1, ∀(s4 ∈ s1, ∀(s5 ∈ s1,(s3[s2]s3 ∧((s3[s2]s4 ∧ s4[s2]s5)→ s3[s2]s5)))))}
  ⊣ d(s0, s1)
  ⊣ d(s1, s2)
  ⊣ d(s1, s3)
  ⊣ d(s1, s4)
  ⊣ d(s1, s5)
  ⊣ d(s0, s2)
  ⊣ d(s0, s3)
  ⊣ d(s0, s4)
  ⊣ d(s0, s5)
  ⊣ d(s2, s3)
  ⊣ d(s2, s4)
  ⊣ d(s2, s5)
  ⊣ d(s3, s4)
  ⊣ d(s3, s5)
  ⊣ d(s4, s5)
}

blocks.name: df-drs
blocks.content: Define the class of directed sets. A directed set is a nonempty preordered set where every pair of elements have some upper bound. Note that it is not required that there exist a _least_ upper bound. There is no consensus in the literature over whether directed sets are allowed to be empty. It is slightly more convenient for us if they are not. (Contributed by Stefan O'Rear, 1-Feb-2015.)

  mpan9(wcel(c0, cproset), w3a(wcel(c1, c2), wcel(c3, c2), wcel(c4, c2)), wa(wbr(c1, c5, c1), wi(wa(wbr(c1, c5, c3), wbr(c3, c5, c4)), wbr(c1, c5, c4))), wral(hs0, c2, wral(hs1, c2, wral(hs2, c2, wa(wbr(cv(hs0), c5, cv(hs0)), wi(wa(wbr(cv(hs0), c5, cv(hs1)), wbr(cv(hs1), c5, cv(hs2))), wbr(cv(hs0), c5, cv(hs2))))))))
